title: Monday, 7th December, 2015
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE

Hi. Hey. Hello. Good morning.

BE

Paul's stuck on a train.

BE

now stuck at deptford with cops all over the train

11:04 am
BE

That was nine minutes ago. We'll keep you updated as to his progress.

BE

And whether the cops are there for a reason. One should assume nothing.

BE

Anyway, that means it's up to me to find a portrait. And any excuse .....

11:05 am
BE

BE

Is it panto season? No! It's Guy Hands, who gets a mention apropos of an interesting pickup in Financial News.

BE

Guy Hands’ private equity firm Terra Firma is being forced to pay up to attract buyers to an auction of stakes in its 2007 fund, a fund made famous by its disastrous investment in music firm EMI.

11:06 am
BE

http://www.efinanc...8a9b64335114be16d0

BE

in an unusual move, Terra Firma has offered to use its own funds to buy 10% of the fund interests investors want to sell. The move has been taken because potential buyers would only be willing to purchase stakes if the Terra Firma invested alongside them, according to a person familiar with the matter.

BE

The firm is using adviser Credit Suisse to run the auction for second hand stakes in the €5.4 billion fund it launched in 2007, which houses part of the firm’s failed £4.5 billion investment in music company EMI Group. Terra Firma and its co-investors lost £1.75 billion on the deal.

11:06 am
BE

Click through for the full story.

BE

So ..... This looks like investors in the 2007 fund are basically insisting that Hands keeps some skin in the game.

BE

Rather than drifting off to focus on closing down care homes, or whatever.

11:08 am
undefined
BE

Right, so, we're up. FTSE ahead 0.5%.

BE

Though the day's trend is that all the oilers are down. Quite heavily.

11:09 am
BE

Which is of course on the back of Friday's shambolic Opec meeting.

Royal Dutch Shell PLC (RDSB:LSE): Last: 1,560, down 39.5 (-2.47%), High: 1,602, Low: 1,558, Volume: 2.01m
BP PLC (BP.:LSE): Last: 353.25, down 6.45 (-1.79%), High: 358.15, Low: 350.60, Volume: 10.71m
11:09 am
BG Group PLC (BG.:LSE): Last: 1,008, down 17.5 (-1.71%), High: 1,027, Low: 1,006, Volume: 1.76m
BHP Billiton PLC (BLT:LSE): Last: 779.10, down 8.6 (-1.09%), High: 790.40, Low: 776.50, Volume: 2.03m
BE

So Opec -- eventually -- says production stays at the current level of 31.5mn b/d.

11:10 am
BE

No decision on a new quota, no agreement on a ceiling of 30mn b/d.

BE

Around which there was some confusion, for want of a better term.

BE

After Bloomberg reported that the ceiling would be raised to 31.5 mb/d ....

11:10 am
BE

.... as in closer in line with effective production.

BE

(Bloomberg) -- Oil dropped after the Organization of
Petroleum Exporting Countries was said to have lifted the
group’s production ceiling to 31.5 million barrels a day.
The new limit doesn’t include output from Indonesia, which
rejoined the group after a break of almost seven years,
according to a delegate with knowledge of the decision. The
previous target was 30 million barrels a day and OPEC pumped
about 31.4 million in October, according to estimates in its
monthly market report.

BE

Yeah, well.

11:12 am
BE

So that didn't happen, which leaves Opec at the mercy of the market.

BE

With Saudi Arabia, which owns more than four fifths of spare capacity, continuing its year-long siege.

BE

Not just against the market but against all other Opec members.

11:12 am
BE

Lots of analysts saying, "no surprises." Because analysts are never surprised by anything.

BE

Here's Natixis.

BE

When Iran was under sanctions and production from non-OPEC was flooding the market, Saudi Arabia took a call a year ago to play the market share strategy and at that time Iran along with some of the weaker OPEC members wanted to cut back production. However, when Saudi Arabia suggested they might be interested to hear from other members this time around, it was almost impossible for the key OPEC members to have agreed as the most powerful members within OPEC have different agendas which have never been so clear than this meeting. Iran clearly walked out happy as it was unlikely to sign up for any production cuts along with Iraq. This time it was Saudi Arabia which looked a bit miffed as Iran suddenly asked to take the same path that Saudi Arabia took 1 year ago. Saudi Arabia, is likely to have taken a bitter pill of keeping oil production unchanged this time having realised there was no way it could have convinced Iran and Iraq to scale back just when they want to either return or ramp up production.

11:13 am
BE

Saudi Arabia’s call last year to not cut back perhaps was right in order to cut out the high cost marginal producers in the world and put political and financial pressure on some of the weaker OPEC members. However, it did not anticipate it would take this long to see the results that it desired. We do believe they would eventually be successful in balancing the markets as non-OPEC and weaker OPEC members’ production slows down, but this time around it would come at a cost to Saudi Arabia. It may not be losing market shar (perhaps not that much), but it would be punished in losing foreign reserves that it had built in the last decade and risk losing the stability within and outside the country the royal family need. This is very likely to be a risky bet for the largest Middle East producer if the low oil price does stay for longer, which it would in a ceilingless OPEC for another 12-18 months, there are high chances of instability rising in Middle East and Saudi Arabia. This seems to be a risk that Saudi Arabia is for now prepared to take as they deem their finances can be managed by reducing expenditure and raising capital in domestic and international bond markets.

BE

(@Mo06: how exciting! I'll have to add that to my year-end round robin.)

BE

We don’t expect much from the next meeting either, as fundamentals based on current OPEC output remain quite weak and there will be limited reason for OPEC to make a joint decision to cut as the market will continue to remain oversupplied even by June 2016. OPEC’s expectation of non-OPEC support is also unrealistic for now. We expect oil prices to remain low at least for 2016H1 and perhaps also for the rest of 2016 if OPEC continues with its policy on producing as much as they can without a ceiling. It’s only when all members of OPEC are producing at their optimum levels, will OPEC once again be more powerful and be able to balance the markets or control oil prices.

11:14 am
BE

And Oddo.

BE

The tug of war with shale oil production is continuing
The success of this strategy is still mixed. US crude production dropped by just 400 kb/d approximately in November to 9.2 mb/d (of which 5.06 mb/d of shale oil) from its peak of 9.66 kb/d in June (over the past year it even increased slightly) and should probably fall by 600 kb/d in 2016. Behind Saudi Arabia's tougher exterior, we detect some nervousness about the risk of a low oil price in 2016 since this is weighing on its finances (reserves down by over $ 100bn with fiscal breakeven at around $ 98/b) and especially those of other non-Gulf members. This is increasing tension within OPEC. Saudi Arabia is surprised by: i/ the resilience of US production with costs being cut, financing maintained and production hedged by futures contracts renewed when the price rose in May 2015; and ii/ the removal of sanctions on Iran, which it was not expecting. OPEC preferred to save time and press on with its strategy of observing the impact on rival production and perhaps also negotiate with Iran and Russia which until now did not want to take part in cutting production. OPEC will probably end up acknowledging the responsiveness of shale oil producers which can resume production once oil prices return to more attractive levels.

BE

Our scenario for the oil price is maintained
The fall in production costs in industry and the responsiveness of shale oil producers which can resume production if ever price levels became profitable back up our scenario of a Brent price of $ 50/60/65/b in 2016/2017/2018. The current oversupply levels of 1.2 mb will only be reduced in 2017. The price will converge with the cost of $ 62/b for the marginal oil supply created by shale oil.

11:15 am
undefined
BE

Update: Paul hasn't been taken out by Jihadists. He's made it into the office.

BE

Unfortunately, he has been taken out by IT.

11:16 am
BE

Who are in many ways a more formidable enemy. There's a new password routine this morning and his computer's failing it.

BE

He'll join us eventually. But not yet.

undefined
11:17 am
BE

Since we've mentioned oil, should just follow with miners.

BE

Iron ore just gone sub $40

BE

Lowest since the credit crunch.

11:18 am
BE

Sector quite calm, though. You'll have read this overnight, I guess.

BE

http://www.ft.com/...html#axzz3tdCGYHVz

BE

Glencore, the resources group hit by falling commodity prices, is to tell investors that it expects to complete its $10.2bn debt reduction plan before the end of 2016, earlier than previously expected.
The Swiss-based company also plans to use a call with investors on Thursday to highlight the progress it is making with a disposal programme and the additional steps it can take if commodity prices remain weak, according to three people familiar with Glencore’s plans.

11:19 am
BE

Can Glencore cut debt faster than its industrial side burns money? It'll be exciting to find out.

BE

Here's RBC's year-start mining outlook.

BE

Following the dismal price performance in 2015, we expect a modest improvement in 2016: We expect an improvement in global economic growth, combined with ongoing production curtailments, to lead to a bottom in non-precious metal commodity prices in 2016 and a gradual improvement in prices beginning in 2017.
Downward revisions to our economic growth assumptions and continued commodity price declines result in significant price forecast downgrades:
• Base metal downgrades significant; an 18% decrease in our average Ni price forecast, an 11% decrease in Zn, a 14% decrease in Cu, and a 12% decrease in Al.
• Bulk commodity price revisions more modest; a 19% decrease in our average coking coal price forecast, a 10% decrease in iron ore, and an 8% decrease for thermal coal.
• Substantive cuts to PGM and titanium feedstock prices also.
• Uranium price forecasts unchanged.

11:20 am
BE

We are in the seasonally strongest period of the year for global non-precious metals mining shares and the commodities.
At a 39.6% discount to NAV at our forecast prices, the shares appear very attractive trading at trough of cycle valuations: At the same time, the shares finally represent good value relative to the underlying commodities, trading at an 18.9% discount to NAV at forward curve prices.

BE

We continue to recommend a cautious approach, but look for trading opportunities: We recommend generalist investors hold an underweight position in non-precious metals mining shares and focus on companies with strong balance sheets and solid funding positions. Attractive valuations and strong seasonality, combined with a modest improvement on the macroeconomic front, could drive a seasonal rally. However, any improvement in share prices may have to wait until after the tax loss selling season in late December or early January again this year.
Preferred commodities: Our preferred commodities based on our 2016 price forecasts are zinc, nickel and uranium, and based on our five-year forecasts are nickel, zinc, and iron ore.
Recommended Shares:
• Australia: Western Areas
• Europe: Anglo Pacific, Sierra Rutile, Tronox
• Global Diversifieds: Teck
• North America: Lundin Mining, Ivanhoe, Labrador Iron Ore, Cameco, Uranium Participation Corp.
• PGM’s: Impala Platinum, Platinum Group Metals

BE

So, don't buy anything. Basically.

11:22 am
undefined
BE

Paul's still trying to log in. He's reached the page that asks about favourite childhood pets and memorable 12-digit numbers.

BE

What can we do in the meantime? I'm cautious do mention Avanti .......

11:23 am
BE

.... which the ROTR is excited by.

Avanti Communications Group PLC (AVN:LSE): Last: 188.84, up 7.59 (+4.18%), High: 197.00, Low: 181.00, Volume: 128.13k
BE

There's a mention in De Spiegel noting that Isis probably uses satphones ...

11:24 am
BE

http://www.spiegel...age-a-1066190.html

BE

... Which is interesting, but takes us back to old arguments about whether communications networks should be responsible for their customers.

BE

If you plan a murder on the telephone, is BT an accomplice? That was the old question.

11:26 am
BE

Anyway, in happier news, they've a rural broadband deal on the tape: http://www.investe...1512070700061187I/

BE

I don't know. DYOR.

undefined
11:27 am
BE

Hey, in other smallcap news ........

BE

BE

Hi Bryce.

Please note that the VREQs (voluntary requirements) have now been removed from Plus500’s FCA register page – these were the ‘restrictions’ that you wrote about on 23 November (on Alphaville).

11:28 am
BE

As in, this post: http://ftalphavill...change-at-plus500/

BE

Which was prompted by a load of traders at rival firms getting in contact and saying, "uh, what's going on here?"

BE

The rest of the email is on background, so I can't quote it directly.

11:30 am
BE

Suffice to say, there seems to have been a bit of a snafu through the communications process.

BE

And people familiar with Plus500 aren't too happy with the FCA.

Plus500 Ltd (PLUS:LSE): Last: 492.75, down 7.25 (-1.45%), High: 504.50, Low: 485.00, Volume: 148.01k
11:31 am
BE

Whatever. Good luck to all holders.

undefined
BE

Okay, what else.

11:31 am
BE

Sellside? Sure.

Man Group PLC (EMG:LSE): Last: 165.60, up 2.6 (+1.60%), High: 170.00, Low: 164.10, Volume: 3.12m
BE

Citi pushing.

11:33 am
BE

Cash generated will go either on M&A, or on buybacks, or on both.

BE

Haley Tam is the analyst.

BE

Upgrade to Buy — We raise our management fee EPS forecasts by 6%-17%, and
set a new DCF-based 186p price target. At this target, Man would trade at 12.0x
2017E PE, a 14% discount to peers. Upgrade to Buy from Neutral/High Risk: Man
Group share price volatility has reduced, and so we remove our High Risk rating.
 Yield and Growth — We forecast 14% CAGR 2015-18E in management fee EPS
and therefore in DPS too. 10.4c 2016E DPS = 7.1p, i.e. a 4.3% dividend yield. Man
offers a strong, growing yield, well covered by total EPS (1.7x 2016E).

11:33 am
PM

hi

PM

That was fun

BE

Comfortable with AHL — AHL accounts for 20%-25% FUM and we forecast will
generate 35%-40% net revenue 2016E-18E. In this note we take a ‘deep dive’ into
AHL and our confidence in a stable flow and returns outlook. We set out Bull (254p)
Bear (113p) Base (186p) valuations to illustrate the importance of AHL on page 7

11:34 am
BE

Hidden Value — This confidence in AHL allows us not only to factor fund flow,
performance fee and share buyback expectations into our forecasts, but also to turn
our attention to GLG, FRM and Numeric for future additional growth potential.

BE

 Regulation — We expect asset managers to face increasing regulatory scrutiny in
2016-2017. We see Man well placed for this, thanks to its strong balance sheet,
large size compared to other hedge funds, and its relatively low exposure to those
segments of the industry where we expect to see the greatest operational impact.
 Mainstream Future — As hedge fund investing heads for a more mainstream and
transparent future, we see larger, managed account and full service providers like
Man Group best placed to win fund flows from institutional investors.

BE

Here's page 7.

11:35 am
BE

BE

With clip art.

BE

BE

BE

11:38 am
Serco Group PLC (SRP:LSE): Last: 106.40, down 7.9 (-6.92%), High: 108.70, Low: 99.25, Volume: 6.77m
BE

................... Warns on 2016.

PM

scorchedfingers

11:39 am
BE

Turnaround is on track, but the pain to get to the other side will be a bit more than previously expected.

BE

Serco had a decent rally into these figures, having gradually gained a few supporters on the sellside.

PM

Trading statement here

11:40 am
BE

But it's still a work in progress and I guess today's update reminds everyone of that.

BE

Here's Morgan Stanley.

BE

Today's trading update guides to higher 2015 EBITA, but a weaker
outlook for 2016, with higher than previously expected revenue
attrition and stranded costs driving a lower than expected £50m EBITA
(vs MSe £58m, Cons £72m). Cash flow guidance remains inline with
MSe. While commentary on progress reads well, today's announcement
highlights the ongoing uncertainty and shape of any recovery at Serco,
with guidance suggesting a lower than previously expected trough
likely in 2016-17.

11:41 am
BE

2015 slightly ahead of expectations... : Serco 2015 trading profit is now
expected at ~£95m, vs previous guidance of £90m but with “risks weighted to
the upside”. This has been partly driven by better than expected cost savings,
which have exceeded company £20m target.
...but a warning on 2016 outlook. New guidance for 2016 points to further
downside, with underlying trading profit expected to be £50m (vs MSe £58m,
Cons at £72m). New weaker guidance is due to higher than previously
expected revenue attrition (net revenue loss of £700m, of which £500m of
attrition, up from £350m ), mainly driven by the Americas division.
Management also commented on continued limited progress on new growth
in 2016 as a result of the weak bid pipeline. Management now targets £50m of
cost savings for 2016, included in new EBITA guidance.

PM

Such a weird statement -- from the company itself

BE

Cash outlook remains inline, thanks to lower OCPs. New guidance for
cash flow benefits from recently announced agreements on Balance Sheet
Review items, including the Australian Patrol Boat contract. Net debt for end
2015 is now expected at £100m post BPO disposal (MSe £161m) and for 2016
new guidance is £200-250m (MSe £235m).
Uncertainties remain, valuation still looks stretched on look through
basis. Expectation reset for 2016, and reduced overhang from sale of BPO and
OCP negations point to a potential improvement in the risk-reward for Serco
shares from here. However, we expect increased focus on the future earnings
potential of the business with today's announcement suggesting a lower
2016-17 base. We are mindful of material uncertainties on the shape of any
recovery, but as we have previously highlighted even assuming management's
aspirations of 5-7% growth and 5-6% margins by 2019-20 suggests ~£110-
130m net income, implying a 2020 P/E of

9x vs MSCI Europe on ~10x or put

another way, discounting back to today implies 118p FV or ~4% upside.

11:42 am
BE

There's a bit of football-manager syndrome about it. Doing all they can on the resources they inherited.

BE

Progress being made but results will take time.

PM

haha

11:43 am
BE

Here's Deutsche.

BE

Serco published a trading update originally scheduled for mid-December. We
understand that the reason for the earlier timing is the decision to put out
outlook for 2016E which reflects higher contract attrition than previously
anticipated.

Guidance for underlying trading profit for 2015E was upgraded from £90m to
£95m, in part due to exceeding cost saving targets by £20m helping offset
pressures like lower levels of ad hoc work. The company have commented that
on a reported basis the profit will likely be significantly higher due to onerous
contract provision releases (mainly due to ACPB being renegotiated as
previously communicated) and other contract and balance sheet review items.

Management have now put out an outlook for 2016E. They expect adjusted
profit of £50m in 2016E on revenues of £2.8bn. The bridge between 2015E and
2016E starts from c.£95m of trading profit, taking away c.£20m for the
disposed BPO business, taking away c.£34m of attrition and c.£6m for the end
of the Northern Rail JV, and adding back c.£10m for new business.
Management now expect 2016E revenue attrition of £500m versus £350m
previously. Based on comments on the call we estimate incremental trading
profit attrition of c.£10m. The incremental attrition was mainly due to the
Americas segment where the Virginia DoP contract is being brought back in-
house and the National Benefits Centre rebid was lost. Cost savings for 2016E
are targeted at £50m, which on the call Serco said will mainly be necessary to
offset negative operating leverage due to attrition. Management expect the
savings to be front-end loaded and c.80% (c.£40m) to benefit 2016E.

Free cash flow for 2015E so far was better than previously expected and
management guide to net debt of c.£100m if get the BPO disposal proceeds in
2015E or £300m if the proceeds are received in 2016E. Net debt for 2016E
expected is at £200-250m implying 2.0-2.5x net debt/EBITDA, due to a
c.£100m free cash flow outflow.

BE

We expect the 2016E guidance to lead to downgrades to consensus.
Bloomberg median EBIT for 2016E currently stands at £64m (DB trading profit
at £58m for 2016E) however the range is very wide making it difficult to pin-
point the magnitude of the cuts. In our view, management’s guidance so far
can be described as conservative which could put a floor on cuts. On our
numbers coming into today Serco was trading on 0.4x 2016E EV/Sales and
c.12x EV/EBITDA. We believe that it is difficult to value Serco using earnings
metrics given the profit figures will be volatile due individual contracts and in
our view a long-term DCF is the best valuation methodology.

11:53 am
BE

Here's Investec to summarise.

BE

¢ Iluka considers alternative deals after ending Kenmare talks. Iluka Resources (ILU AU) has ended talks to acquire Kenmare Resources (KMR LN), saying that it will look at alternative deals to foster growth. ILU ended talks after KMR indicated that its largest shareholder wouldn’t support a deal. The company last month cut its offer for KMR because of a fall in prices and a deteriorating market.

¢ Kenmare announces US$175m investment and capital raising plans. The KMR Board is proposing a capital raising and debt restructuring plan to “materially deleverage the balance sheet”. State General Reserve Fund, SGRF, a sovereign wealth fund of Oman, has approved in principle an investment of US$100m in KMR subject to commitments from other shareholders for an additional minimum US$75m. A process of negotiations is expected to take a number of weeks.

BE

Investec view: As one door closes, another opens… This would be a brave, bold move by the sovereign wealth fund and perhaps the start of a wave of the expected selective investments in the mining sector by specialist funds. We expect that KMR’s lenders (last reported total debt of $330m) will be comfortable to see how this capital raising progresses, given the lack of palatable alternative options. Equity shareholders are again being expected to come to the rescue.

11:57 am
undefined
BE

Out of the depths. Anything to wind up with?

BE

Someone downgraded Tesco. That's always worth a line.

11:57 am
Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 160.70, down 1.9 (-1.17%), High: 162.80, Low: 160.15, Volume: 6.63m
BE

Oh, it was Morgan Stanley. Not much wiggle room on the balance sheet, savings countered by trading headwinds, valuation full.

BE

You know the routine. And here it is.

11:58 am
BE

We have been buyers of Tesco shares for the restructuring potential
and the portfolio optimisation story. With the latter being on hold
and headwinds in the UK sector offsetting self-help opportunities at
Tesco, we think valuation is fair today. Move to EW, PT 160p.

BE

Still scope to materially improve UK operations... Tesco's margin-led
strategy in the years preceding its FY15 margin resets not only led to market
share losses but also significantly complicated the business, notably as the
focus on vendor allowances led to assortment proliferation. As Tesco is
drastically cutting back on its SKUs (by a fourth in its largest stores), we expect
efficiency gains in terms of labour, inventory and buying conditions. Also,
potential support from branded goods manufacturers could become a key
weapon in fighting the discounters, as it has been in France.
... but lower balance sheet optionality and short-term trading volatility.
Without further portfolio optimization, Tesco's ability to be much more
aggressive in its domestic market (and thereby put a lid on the discounters'
share gains while forcing competitors to close more stores) is limited. Also,
Tesco's trading in 2H16 will be impacted by heavy couponing last year.
Most importantly, we would continue to avoid UK grocers for now.
Industry headwinds (recent and more structural) are more than offsetting the
recent positive developments in the industry (easing of the deflation, space
growth moderation, etc.). In particular, the price gap to discounters remains
unsustainably high (15-20% as per The Grocer), while the minimum wage hike
could lower the sector's profitability by ~10% by 2020, we calculate.
Our base case DCF yields 160p, our new PT (prev. 220p). We drop our
scenario-based PT for Tesco as we think the shares do not discount a large
probability of our (revised) Bull/Bear cases happening. We see further asset
sales as much less likely now. Our new Base case excludes them, expects
bumpier trading updates short term and FY18 UK margins 30ps lower.
Current valuation seems fair. On our base case assumptions (whereby
Tesco's Group margins reach 3.5% in FY19e), Tesco shares currently trade on
7.0x CY18e EV/EBITDA, in line with the sector average. We think this is fair
given that Tesco's market leading position in the concentrated UK market is
offset by execution risks and exposure to hypermarkets (~50% at Group level).

BE
